criteria: Ability to solve simple rational equations
Ability to solve simple radical equations
descriptions: Student demonstrates no understanding of how to solve rational equations.
Student attempts to solve rational equations but struggles with basic algebraic manipulations.
Student can solve simple rational equations with some errors in algebraic manipulation or simplification.
Student can solve most simple rational equations correctly, with only minor errors.
Student can solve simple rational equations correctly and efficiently, showing a clear understanding of the process.
Student can solve simple rational equations correctly, efficiently, and can explain the reasoning behind each step.
Student demonstrates no understanding of how to solve radical equations.
Student attempts to solve radical equations but struggles with isolating the radical or squaring both sides.
Student can solve simple radical equations with some errors in algebraic manipulation or simplification.
Student can solve most simple radical equations correctly, with only minor errors.
Student can solve simple radical equations correctly and efficiently, showing a clear understanding of the process.
Student can solve simple radical equations correctly, efficiently, and can explain the reasoning behind each step.
Student does not recognize the possibility of extraneous solutions.
Student acknowledges the existence of extraneous solutions but does not know how to identify them.
Student attempts to check for extraneous solutions but makes errors in the process.
Student can identify extraneous solutions in most cases, but may miss some.
Student consistently checks for and identifies extraneous solutions, explaining why they arise.
Student consistently checks for and identifies extraneous solutions, and can explain the mathematical reason behind why extraneous solutions arise.
